abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the District Heating Project
            for Croatia were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: commitment and ownership on the side of
            the Borrower and implementing agencies are important for the
            success of this project. This was demonstrated by the
            capability of the Hrvatska Elektroprivreda Toplinarstvo (HEP
            T) team, which implemented the project on time, even though
            one year of implementation (2008) was lost due to a change
            in the composition of its supervisory management board. A
            key lesson for district heating projects in Europe and
            Central Asia  (ECA) is that politically difficult decisions
            on increasing heat tariffs should be an integral and
            complementary part of the economic dialogue underpinnings
            (DPLs) (as is the case in Ukraine and Moldova). A simple and
            focused project design helps in effective implementation and
            achieving the project objectives. It is important to have
            continuity in the implementing agency's management
            team. For example, HEP T's Supervisory Board was
            changed after the change of government in 2008, and this
            change caused a one year delay in project implementation due
            to the new Board's unfamiliarity with the Bank's
            procurement procedures. The size of procurement packages for
            works (in this case for pipe installation works) should be
            designed in such a way that several local companies have the
            financial capability and implementation capacity to execute
            them, thus allowing adequate competition. There should be
            financial incentives for tenants to implement Demand Side
            Management (DSM) measures in apartment buildings. As long as
            the heat tariff is low and there is no incentive for
            investment, apartment owners are not likely to be keen on
            accepting voluntary Debt Management Section (DMS).
